title: Email spoofing possible via Legal Robot domain

profile.name: Legal Robot
profile.about: Automated legal document review using artificial intelligence

vulnerability_information:
Dear Team,

There are few email spoofing tools available on for free and one of them is http://emkei.cz/
When i tried to send an email from hello@legalrobot.com to my mail, it was successful and straight away delivered into my inbox but when i tried to send it from another mail id swapnil@facebook.com,amrutapkothawade@gmail.com, i did not receive any mail.

Hence there might be some configuration missing in your mail servers (i am not much aware of technical details associated with this issue but would love to know how this is happening)

This can be dangerous, as attacker can send some fake mails with any fake promotional mails and ask for account details or it can be anything.This thing can also lead to reputation loss.

PFA screenshots of mail delivered to my account.Please feel free if you need any further help.

Thanks & Regards,

Swapnil Kothawade.

activities.message: Thanks for the report, however we already provide DMARC, DKIM, and SPF records on our DNS server, which provides the extent of what's currently possible in combating email spoofing. If you notice in the top left hand corner of your screenshot, there is a small red lock in the unlocked position. This is a feature that gmail provides to warn users that the email may be spoofed. So, while it it technically possible to spoof an email from our domain (or most) we use best practices in combating these and it is up to the receiving email server to classify the message accordingly. For more detail see http://blog.endpoint.com/2014/04/spf-dkim-and-dmarc-brief-explanation.html

activities.message:
Report #575 was submitted to another bug bounty program. Not every program on HackerOne has the same rules, which is why the policies that apply to each program are clearly provided on the program page. Most importantly, the report you submitted does not demonstrate any problems with our system (perhaps email in general).

Moreover, problems with our DMARC, DKIM, and SPF records are all valid for reporting - but you have not demonstrated any deficiency in those DNS records.

activities.message:
Email looks to be general because i have composed it in simple way on the other end an attacker can compose any fake promotional email and send it to user or can ask for important details or it can be any malicious activity. 
According to me it is some misconfiguration in your server and improper setting of SPF records that’s why it directly got delivered to my in-box and that too my gmail account and around 70-80% people use gmail.If your SPF records were proper then it would have been delivered to my spam box.

Hope this explanation makes it clear that it is a valid bug and need to be fixed.Rest it's upto you whether to fix it or not.

Thanks & Regards,

Swapnil Kothawade

Thanks. Unfortunately we can't control what Gmail decides to deliver or send to spam. We have three domains listed in our SPF record and use a hard blocking rule for all others (-all). Here is the validation output:

	
	SPF record lookup and validation for: legalrobot.com

	v=spf1 include:mailgun.org include:_spf.google.com include:spf.mail.intercom.io -all 
	google-site-verification=U5MZ7I0GLcba89znORPLf8ZMf0gYImshw3LM9mx-M3Y 
	google-site-verification=W9XdSBds8vGgPuEmzykor8-NN3Tmxks7WZGdBh3Jls4

	v=spf1 include:mailgun.org include:_spf.google.com include:spf.mail.intercom.io -all

If you can find a problem, we'd be glad to hear of it.
Happy hacking!
